reporting_cycle: The Secretary-General reports to the Council within four months on a plan for UN system support to specific peacebuilding tasks, and then regularly every four months
summary:
The Security Council,

Welcoming the establishment of the Republic of South Sudan on 9 July 2011, reaffirms its strong commitment to the sovereignty, independence, territorial integrity, and national unity of the Republic of South Sudan.

The Council stresses the need for a comprehensive approach to peace consolidation, integrating political, security, development, human rights, and rule of law activities, and addressing underlying causes of conflict.

It deplores the persistence of conflict and violence, and underscores the need for sustained cooperation and dialogue with civil society to stabilize the security situation and protect civilians.

The Council emphasizes the vital role of the UN in supporting national authorities to consolidate peace, prevent a return to violence, and develop an early strategy in support of national peacebuilding priorities.

These priorities include establishing core government functions, providing basic services, establishing the rule of law, respecting human rights, managing natural resources, developing the security sector, tackling youth unemployment, and revitalizing the economy.

The Council recognizes the importance of supporting peacebuilding efforts for sustainable development and forging stronger partnerships among the UN, development agencies, bilateral partners, and other actors.

It underscores the need for the Security Council to show flexibility in adjusting mission priorities according to progress achieved, lessons learned, or changing circumstances.

The Council also recognizes the need to broaden and deepen the pool of available civilian experts, especially women and experts from developing countries, to help develop national capacity.

Recalling previous resolutions and statements, the Council reaffirms its commitment to protecting civilians, humanitarian personnel, and UN personnel, and to promoting women, peace, and security.

The Council specifically recalls resolutions 1612 (2005) and 1882 (2009) on children and armed conflict, and resolutions 1674 (2006) and 1894 (2009) on the protection of civilians in armed conflict. 

The Council also reaffirms resolutions 1325 (2000), 1820 (2008), 1888 (2009), 1889 (2009), and 1960 (2010) on women, peace, and security.
